posts.body:
Peter H. Clark

An abolitionist and educator, Peter H. Clark (1829-1925) in considered the first Black socialist in the United States.

Clark was born in Cincinnati, Ohio. His family highly valued education–his father sent him to private schools because there were no Black public schools, until his uncle (John Isom Gaines), led the effort to have Black schools authorized by the Ohio legislature. Clark became the first teacher in this school until he was fired by the (White) Board of Education for publically praising Thomas Paine (a White man who helped start the American Revolution, today considered a hero and an uncontroversial figure).

Clark worked as an abolitionist, writing, publishing, and editing newspapers and was appointed the secretary of the 1853 National Convention of Colored Men by Frederick Douglass. Clark was also a conductor for the Underground Railroad.

He was a member of the Free Soil Party (a single-issue political party dedicated to opposing the expansion of slavery into new US territories in the West) until he was rehired to teach in Cincinnati. Here, he founded a union for Black teachers.

In 1878, Clark ran for Congress as a member of the Socialist Labor Party of America of Ohio’s first congressional district. He said ““The welfare of the Negro is my controlling political motive.”

posts.body:
Jean-Michel Basquiat

[A portrait of Basquiat by Andy Warhol in 1982].

A New York-born artist of Haitian and Puerto Rican descent, Jean-Michel Basquiat (1960-1988) was a successful Black, queer artist. At just 21 years old, Basquiat became the youngest artist to ever take part in documenta, an important international exhibition, in Kassel, Germany.

Born in Brooklyn, Basquiat grew up going to the many art museums the city had to offer. He was also very academically inclined–he could read and write by age four and was fluent in three languages (French, Spanish, and English) by eleven. However, his childhood was troubled. He was hit by a car when he was 7, his parents separated and his mother spent much of his life in and out of psychiatric hospitals. He rebelled against his father, doing drugs and running away from home, until he was eventually kicked out of school (for pieing the principal) and kicked out of his father’s house (for being kicked out of school).

In 1978, Basquiat and Al Diaz, as the artistic duo SAMO, began graffitiing buildings in Manhattan. Their art immediately began popular, appearing in The Village Voice and on public-access TV. Basquiat made friends with up-and-coming artists of the late 20th century, including Keith Haring and Andy Warhol. Basquiat was a bisexual man.

In 1983, a Black artist named Michael Stewart, was killed by New York City Transit Police. Basquiat was deeply affected by this. His work had always discussed race and oppression, but Defacement (The Death of Michael Stewart), his 1983 painting still reverberates particularly hard.

posts.body:
Ida B. Wells

A journalist and educator, Ida B. Wells (1862-1931) was an early leader in the civil rights movement and one of the founders of the NAACP.

Wells was born a slave and freed by the Emancipation Proclamation as an infant. One of eight children, Wells’ parents died when she was 16 and she began working as a teacher to keep her family together. When refusing to give up her first-class seat and subsequently being dragged out, she began receiving fame and notoriety as an activist with her written account of the vent and her following legal battles. She was eventually fired by the Memphis Board of Education for articles criticizing conditions in Black schools

As a journalist, much of her work was covering racially motivated lynchings. Ida Wells was one of the foremost voices in the anti-lynching movement, publishing articles in the Free Speech. However, in 1892, White-owned newspapers began publishing threats against the Free Speech, and its office was ransacked and destroyed. Wells moved up to Harlem, working for the New York Age and continuing to focus on her anti-lynching campaign. She published a pamphlet called Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases which discussed false accusations of Black men raping White women as a smokescreen for the real reason for lynchings: preventing Black economic and social progress.

Wells was acquainted with and supported by Frederick Douglass, but after his death, her relatively radical positions (especially her feminist ones, in a civil rights movement that still prioritized male leadership) put her at occasional odds with others like Booker T. Washington and W. E. B. Du Bois. In addition to her work and leadership with groups like the NAACP and the National Equal Rights League, she was also active in women’s clubs, including the National Association of Colored Women’s Clubs.

During World War I, Wells was placed under surveillance by the U.S. government for being a ‘race agitator’. In addition to her civil rights and feminist ideals, Wells was also interested in worker’s rights, supporting the Brotherhood of Sleeping Car Porters, the first Black labor organization to receive a charter in the American Federation of Labor.

This is a very short list of the accomplishments of Ida B. Wells–she did far, far more, and I highly encourage those of you interested in reading Crusade for Justice: The Autobiography of Ida. B Wells.

posts.body:
Claudette Colvin

“History kept me stuck to my seat. I felt the hand of Harriet Tubman pushing down on one shoulder and Sojourner Truth pushing down on the other.”

An American civil rights activist, Claudette Colvin (1939) was one of two of the first Black women to refuse to give up her seat to a White woman on a segregated bus.

Born in Birmingham, Alabama and raised in Pine Level, Colvin was a good student. She attended Booker T. Washington High School and, at 13 years old, was a member of the NAACP Youth Council. Rosa Parks was her mentor.

On March 2nd, 1955, Colvin and another Black woman, Ruth Hamilton, were ordered to move for a White woman. Colvin and Hamilton were both pregnant, and Colvin was using the bus to get to and from high school.

A Black man gave up his seat for Hamilton, but Colvin was arrested. She was sexually harassed by the arresting officers and tried and convicted (in juvenile court) on obviously false charges (most notably, assaulting a police officer). Her criminal record was expunged in 2021.

Colvin was supported by the Black civil rights community in Alabama, but the event was kept quiet until Rosa Parks repeated it. As a pregnant, unmarried teenager with darker skin and textured hair, the movement felt that Rosa Parks was a more sympathetic figure.

In 1956, Colton was among the plaintiffs for Browder v. Gayle, the court case that ultimately got city bus segregation declared unconstitutional.

posts.body:
Frank X Walker

An African-American poet from Kentucky, Frank X Walker (b. 1961) focuses on the importance of Black people in creating and controlling their own narratives.

Walker was born in Danville, Kentucky, as one of eleven children who lived in public housing projects. He attended the University of Kentucky for his Bachelors and Spalding University for his Masters in Fine Arts in Writing.

Walker coined the term ‘Affrilachia’ in the 1990s to discuss the unique experiences and perspectives of Black people in Appalachia. He is a founding member of the Affrilachian Poets and the founding editor of PLUCK!, the new Journal of Affrilachian Art & Culture. He has published multiple books, helped make and produce videos, and has changed how the world has thought about Appalachian identity.

Walker teaches English at the University of Kentucky and was the Poet Laureate of Kentucky. He has won, among other awards, the NAACP Image Award for Outstanding Literary Work in Poetry.

See Frank X Walker’s website here.
An early example of an Affrilachian writer, Bessie Woodson Yancey, was the subject of yesterday’s post.

posts.body:
Bessie Woodson Yancey

Bessie Woodson Yancey (1882-1958) was an African American poet and activist.

Born in New Canton, Virginia to former slaves who emphasized education, she quickly moved through school and became a teacher. She taught in the mining camps of West Virginia, where she also began to write poetry. She only published a single book, a collection of poems entitled Echoes from the Hills (1939), that is a famous–maybe the earliest–example of Affrilachian children’s literature.

Affrilachia is the collective cultural contributions of African Americans artists in the Appalachian mountains. This region is, compared to much of the country, poor and rural, with an economy based on logging and mining. While Appalachia is stereotypically seen as White, Black people have been creating culture in the region for centuries.

Thought often included in discussions on the Harlem Renaissance, the cultural revival of Black artists mostly in Northern urban areas, Affrilachian art like Yancey’s was unique in tone, identity, and purpose. Both of these Black artistic movements were happening near each other and at the same time, but were diverse in the artistic goals and outputs.

In addition to her poetry, Yancey wrote letters and editorials on civil rights and desegregation.

Her brother was Carter G. Woodson, the subject of yesterday’s post.
The term Affrilachia was coined by Frank X Walker, the subject of tomorrow’s post.

posts.body:
Carter G. Woodson

Often called the “father of Black history”, Carter Godwin Woodson (1875-1950) was an American historian and scholar. He is the only person in history with parents enslaved in the U.S.A. to obtain a Ph.D., which he received from Harvard University. He also was the dean of Howard University.

Woodson was born on a farm in New Canton, Virginia. His parents, former slaves, were both illiterate but encouraged education and self-improvement in all their children. Woodson was unable to attend school regularly but taught himself as a child. At 17, he worked in coal mines to afford an education at Douglass High School.

Woodson would go on to earn his Bachelor’s in Literature from Berea College, a Bachelor’s and a Master’s in the Arts from the University of Chicago, and finally his Ph.D. in history at Harvard University in 1912.

Despite his qualifications and brilliance, Woodson found that that mainstream history was not interested in neither Black history nor Black historians–he couldn’t find work as a university professor and was not allowed to attend conferences of the American Historical Association. Seeing the institutional obstacles, Woodson desired to create an institution that did value Black history.

He founded the Association for the Study of Negro Life and History (now the Association for the Study of African American Life and History) in Chicago, published multiple books, and started the Journal of Negro History (now the Journal of African American History). Woodson believed that history belonged to all people, and made an effort to reach outside of academia to women’s groups, civic leaders, fraternal organizations, the clergy, and more. Woodson saw the collection and dissemination of Black history as essential activism in a world that attempted to ignore and deny it and was important for all people. He wanted “the world see the Negro as a participant rather than as a lay figure in history”.

In 1926, Woodson pioneered “Negro History Week” which, in 50 years, become Black History Month. Its purpose was to

“emphasise not Negro History, but the Negro in History. What we need is not a history of selected races or nations, but the history of the world void of national bias, race hatred and religious prejudice”.

His sister was Bessie Woodson Yancey, the subject of tomorrow’s post. Happy Black History Month, everybody!

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Princess Sela

One of the first known female pirates, Princess Sela (active c. 400-420 CE) was a Norwegian princess. This would be centuries before the Viking Age hit Scandanavia.

Only a single sentence in the Gesta Danorum attests to her existence.

Deinde sororem eius, Selam nomine, piraticis exercitam rebus ac bellici peritam muneris, persecutus occidit.

Then he (Horwendill) pursued that (King Koller of Norway)’s sister, with the name Sela, skilled in piracy and experience in war and killer her.

From this, we know that Sela was a princess, brother to the king, and a respected and feared pirate on her own merit. She was killed in battle by a political rival, perhaps fearing her reprisal for his regicide.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Pre-contact Native American Cities

There were a number of large population centers in the Americas. I will be focusing on those in what is now the US and Canada, but large cities also existed south of the Rio Grande.

Generally considered the greatest pre-Columbian Native American city, Cahokia once sat directly across the river from what is now St. Louis, Missouri. It was settled around 600 CE and existed from 1050-1350 CE, with its apex around 1100 CE. Cahokia likely had more than 20,000 people living in (thousands more than London, at the time) and was the most influential urban settlement of the Mississippian culture.

Cahokia, on the Mississippi River, was an important center for trade and agriculture. It maintained trade links with communities from the Great Lakes to the Gulf Coast and had people living outside the main urban center. Cahokia, and the Mississippians who built it, were known for their incredible urban planning and the mounds that made up the city center. Today, the Cahokia Mounds are a UNESCO World Heritage site.

Second, the Poverty Point (named after a 19th-century plantation on top of it) culture was centralized in what is now northeastern Louisiana. Like Cahokia, it had a number of important mounds for urban life. It was constructed over multiple generations, and radiocarbon dating suggests that earthwork construction was in progress from 1800-1200 BCE. Poverty Point is one of the most ancient cities in the Americas. Poverty Point had a rich material culture include fired earthware, copperwork, and stone vessels. They had manufacturing and long-distance trade.

Third, the Calusa (Caloosahatchee) people of the southwest coast of Florida, on the coast of the Gulf. They also built mounds and, at the time of European contact in the 16th century, had a population in the 10,000s. They were likely the only indigenous North Americans who established a kingdom without practicing agriculture, using the abundant fishing resources instead. The main mound, Mound Key, was a manmade structure with canals, watercourts, and other features. The Calusa were notable for their carved-wood art and their sophisticated engineering and architecture. A single manor on Mound Key was capable of holding 2,000 people.

Fourth, the Mogollon culture was one of the major cultures of southwest America. It had multiple large and dense settlements, but one that’s considered a proper city. Called Paquimé, it was settled from 1130-1450 CE. It had a population in the thousands, who lived in multi-story buildings and an irrigation-based agricultural economy. They had a complex system of water control that included drainage, reservoirs, channels, and sewage. The city had a market, ballcourts, and the production of copper and ceramic objects.

The final city to discuss is Etzanoa. Located in what is now Arkansas City, Kansas on the Arkansas River, it actually flourished after and alongside European contact, mostly with the Spanish. Etzanoa housed approximately 20,000 people. It was a seat of power for the Wichita and a trading hub.


[Image Description: A black and white map of the United States. States are outlined but not labeled. Five stars mark the location of cities. Cahokia is on the border of Arkansas and Illinois. Etzanoa is on the border of Kansas and Oklahoma. Poverty Point is on the border of Louisiana and Mississippi. Mound Key is in southern Florida. Paquimé is slightly below New Mexico.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Captain Robert Smalls

A former slave turned politician and ship captain, Robert Smalls (1839-1915) was one of the heroes of the American Civil War.

His mother was a house slave and his father was an unknown white man. Smalls worked in the fields until the age of 12, when he was hired out to work in the dockyards of Charleston, South Carolina.

After the start of the Civil War in 1861, Smalls had proven his worth around boats enough to be a wheelman (essentially a helmsman, but without the prestige of the title reserve for White people). Smalls was assigned to work on the CSS Planter, a military transport ship with the job of laying mines and delivering supplies around the Confederate waterways.

In May 1862, Smalls had permission for the families of the slaves to visit the ship while the White officers disembarked, leaving the slaves on board overnight. At 3am, Smalls put on a captain’s uniform and guided the ship across Confederate waters and up to the Union Navy fleet and put up a white bed sheet as a flag. at Fort Sumter, Smalls and the Planter made contact with the USS Onward, where he surrendered the ship and its cargo, making all onboard free men.

Just 23 years old, Smalls became known as a wartime hero across the North and a hated man in the South. Smalls worked for the Union Navy, and then the Army, where he was known as one of the best and brightest men of any race. Smalls was present at 17 major battles and engagements, particularly useful in helping ships avoid the mines that he had previously laid.

After the war, Smalls returned to South Carolina, where he purchased his former master’s house, started a school for former slaves, and was elected to the United States House of Representatives.

posts.body:
Jonathan Larson

The American musician who wrote Rent, Jonathan Larson (1960-1996) never got to see it live.

Born in White Plains, New York to a Russian-Jewish family, Larson was interested in stagecraft from an early age. After graduating from Adelphi University, he moved to a loft with no heat in Lower Manhattan, where he worked as a waiter and composing in his free time.

His first professional work, a sci-fi musical called Superbia, was never picked up and his second work, an autobiographical work named tick, tick.. BOOM! was performed off-Broadway, but never became particularly famous while he was alive

In 1989, Larson began working with Billy Aronson on a musical update of Puccini’s La Bohème. Aronson left the project, and Rent became a semiautobiographical story set in the East Village about the AIDs Crisis.

January 25th, 1996, Larson died in his house due to an aortic dissection. The next night was Rent’s premier.

Larson won, posthumously, a Pulitzer, multiple Tonys, a few Drama Desk Awards, and more. He lived under the shadow of poverty, illegal heating his apartment, but his name is now better known then ever.

The American musician who wrote Rent, Jonathan Larson (1960-1996) never got to see it live.

Born in White Plains, New York to a Russian-Jewish family, Larson was interested in stagecraft from an early age. After graduating from Adelphi University, he moved to a loft with no heat in Lower Manhattan, where he worked as a waiter and composing in his free time.

His first professional work, a sci-fi musical called Superbia, was never picked up and his second work, an autobiographical work named tick, tick.. BOOM! was performed off-Broadway, but never became particularly famous while he was alive

In 1989, Larson began working with Billy Aronson on a musical update of Puccini’s La Bohème. Aronson left the project, and Rent became a semiautobiographical story set in the East Village about the AIDs Crisis.

January 25th, 1996, Larson died in his house due to an aortic dissection. The next night was Rent’s premier.

Larson won, posthumously, a Pulitzer, multiple Tonys, a few Drama Desk Awards, and more. He lived under the shadow of poverty, illegal heating his apartment, but his name is now better known then ever.
trail.content:

posts.body:
Lillian Ngoyi

Called Mma Ngoyi, Lilian Masediba Matabane Ngoyi (1911-1980) was a South African anti-apartheid activist and a politician.

Born and raised to a washerwoman and a miner, Ngoyi studied to be a nurse and married a van driver. In 1937, her husband died in a car accident, leaving Ngoyi a widow with two children and her elderly mother.

In 1952, she joined the African National Congress Women’s League; within a year she would be its president. Her activism focused on the intersection of race and gender: she led the 1956 Women’s March to protest gendered apartheid laws. She also helped launch the Federation of South African Women.

Ngoyi also understood the importance of international recognition–she traveled illegally to the World Congress of Mothers in Switzerland, before going on a world trip and returning to South Africa wanted. In 1956, she was arrested. Ngoyi spent 71 days in solitary confinement and was confined to her home for 15 years.

posts.body:
The First Restaurant

While food has always been prepared and consumed outside the home–indeed, food preparation predates settlements, the first example of what we’d call a restaurant did not start until about 1100 CE in China.

Chinese urban centers with Hangzhou and Kaifeng had over a million people each. During this time, the Song period, Kaifeng was the northern capital and Hangzhou was the southern capital, and trade flowed freely and easily between them.

Unused to the local cuisine, each city restaurants of the other, so northerners could eat northern cooking in the south and vice versa. Like restaurants of today, they had tables, menus, waiters, and chefs.
